Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing a wide variety of phenomena. However, its foundations have been the subject of intense debate for more than a century. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is based on the notion of a Hilbert category, which is a generalization of a category that is appropriate for the description of quantum systems.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoans to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. We find that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to P. hydriforme. We also find that myxozoans are among the most reduced animals in terms of genome size and gene content. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This is likely to be a common feature of parasitic eukaryotes.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune system is a key factor in their ability to cause disease. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 is able to evade the host immune system and may provide a target for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. The global mean temperature is expected to increase by 2 °C or more by the end of the century. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase to 86% in the top four maize-exporting countries under 4 °C of global warming. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of plant foods is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the formation of other planetary systems. The solar system is also a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the elements. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the elements.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is the most important biological function in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most variable. We show that the ability to reproduce is the most variable in placental mammals, and that the ability to reproduce is the most important factor in determining the evolution of placental mammals.

Alpha-synuclein (α-syn) is a protein that is involved in many different cellular processes. In the brain, it is involved in the regulation of synaptic transmission and in the formation of the myelin sheath. In addition, it is involved in the pathogenesis of several neurodegenerative disorders, including multiple system atrophy (MSA). In MSA, α-syn accumulates in oligodendrocytes, which are the cells responsible for the formation of the myelin sheath. In this study, we show that the inflammatory protease caspase-1 is involved in the mechanisms that promote aggregation of α-syn in vitro and in neuronal cell models of MSA. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study opens the way to the development of a clinical trial in MSA patients.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, regulates blood pressure, and controls inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to respond to a wide variety of stimuli. It does so by sending and receiving information from other cells. The communication system between endothelial cells is poorly understood. Here, we show that the communication system is a network of cells that is highly connected and has a small-world configuration. This configuration is effective for both local and global communication and is therefore optimal for the control of the functions of the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor and respond to the pandemic. However, the data are often difficult to access and use. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a rich set of data on COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are useful for tracking the pandemic, for epidemiological research, and for informing public health policy. The data are also useful for researchers who wish to backfill historical data. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to the research community and to policy makers.

This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health of the host. However, the potential for the microbiome to influence the health of the host is not fully understood. One way in which the microbiome may influence the host is by producing natural products that are secreted into the gut lumen. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the natural products produced by anaerobic fungi, which are a group of gut microbes that have not been previously studied for their potential to produce natural products. The results of this study suggest that anaerobic fungi are a promising source of natural products that could be harnessed for the benefit of the host.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. It is established by the most aggressive individual in a dyad, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance. We identify a key role for the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens, a key structure in the control of social behavior. Our findings point to a potential avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we develop a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple materials that can precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme responses. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The discovery of the optimal composite structures and their physical realization provide a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses. This work is expected to inspire the development of new materials and structures with unprecedented functionalities.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen carrier in the blood. The hemoglobin content of the blood is regulated by the expression of the globin genes. The globin genes are expressed in a developmental manner, with the fetal globin genes expressed in the fetus and the adult globin genes expressed in the adult. The hemoglobin content of the blood is also regulated by the presence of the fetal hemoglobin, which is expressed in the fetus but not in the adult. In this study, we show that the expression of the fetal hemoglobin is regulated by the expression of a protein, IGF2BP1, which is expressed in the fetus but not in the adult.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to current therapies. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop new strategies to treat cancer. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we show that SREBP1-mediated ferroptosis resistance can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway may be a promising strategy to overcome ferroptosis resistance in cancer. Furthermore, the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising approach for cancer treatment. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the management of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings suggest that the use of LCCBs should be limited in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. It also provides a basis for the development of new drugs for the treatment of heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the policy failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy on biodiversity. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo. The best compound designed by us is active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens and shows synergistic activity with colistin. The approach presented here is a promising tool for the rational design of new antibiotics. It can be used to identify new compounds with a high potential for the treatment of antibiotic-resistant infections. The approach is applicable to other antibiotics as well.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The resulting architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to extend to more complex problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-shift the circadian clock, and reduce sleep quality. Here we show that this practice also reduces the amount of time it takes to fall asleep and the amount of time spent in deep sleep, which is critical for the consolidation of memory and the restoration of the body. These effects are likely to have important implications for the health and safety of the user and those around them.

One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the Younger Dryas cooling at ∼12.9 ka. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the periphery and in tolerance is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, which was not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the periphery and in tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles was shaped by the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. Our approach can also be extended to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and drugs against other viruses. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is the most common isoform in the general population and increases AD risk by ∼12-fold. APOE2 is the least common isoform and decreases AD risk by ∼2-fold. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 1,300 km in radius. It is the only solid region in the Earth that is not in equilibrium with the liquid outer core. The inner core is a mystery because it is not known how it formed. The most popular theory is that it formed by the rapid solidification of the outer core. However, this theory is not supported by the fact that the inner core is not in equilibrium with the liquid outer core. We show that the inner core is likely to have formed by a two-step process. In the first step, the molten iron cooled below the melting point. In the second step, the molten iron solidified into the stable, hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This blunted reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are key features of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and its neural basis is a major focus of neuroscience today. However, the nature of these mechanisms is unknown. Here, we show that the most popular deep learning models for natural language processing also outperform humans on a key language comprehension task. We then show that these models’ neural activity can be predicted from the model’s architecture, suggesting that the models are capturing the key computations that underlie language comprehension. These results provide the first computational evidence for the nature of the neural basis of language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still in its infancy and faces many challenges. One of the most fundamental challenges is the instability of DL algorithms. This paper addresses this challenge by establishing a classification theory of the conditions under which one can compute stable neural networks (NNs) with a given accuracy. We prove that, for a large class of well-conditioned problems, one can compute a NN with a given accuracy using only a small number of training samples. This is a significant step toward the development of a stable DL technology.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past epidemics. This is a dangerous misconception. The failure to learn from the 1918 influenza pandemic is often cited as a prime example of how people fail to understand exponential growth. However, this is a misrepresentation of a classic psychological experiment published in 1975. The study’s critical design flaws were not only overlooked at the time but are now being used to support a conclusion that was never the study’s purpose.

Leprosy is a neglected disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense study for more than a century. However, the identity of the causative agent of a related disease, diffuse lepromatous leprosy, remains unknown. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, the causative agent of diffuse lepromatous leprosy. Our results suggest that M. lepromatosis is a close relative of M. leprae and that the two bacilli have retained many of the same functions. This study provides a resource for future studies of the biology of this pathogen. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science. They are also the two main quantities that are not conserved in time in quantum mechanics. Therefore, they are the two main quantities that are not conserved in time in quantum mechanics. In the last decade, the study of the time evolution of these quantities has been at the center of a very active research field. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be completely understood in the space–time scaling limit. This is a very general result that applies to a large class of systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that has claimed millions of lives. The development of a vaccine is the only way to end this pandemic. The only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development, COVI-VAC, is based on a recoded version of the virus. The recoding process was designed to make the vaccine strain less virulent, thereby reducing the risk of severe disease and death in vaccinated individuals. The vaccine strain was also engineered to lack the furin cleavage site within the spike protein, which is a known virulence factor. The vaccine was shown to be safe and immunogenic in hamsters and to protect them from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. These results support the use of COVI-VAC in mass vaccination programs. The vaccine is currently in phase I/II clinical trials in humans. The results presented here provide a detailed description of the vaccine and its development. The results also provide a rationale for the use of this vaccine in mass vaccination programs. Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is characterized by high mortality and recurrent epidemics. The vector of the disease is still debated, with rodent, flea, or human transmission being the most likely. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks better than models for rodent or flea transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of the brain is the most important factor in the rise of complex cognition. However, the evolution of brain size is not a good proxy for the evolution of brain power because it is biased by the evolution of body size. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling: (i) the evolution of a large brain relative to body size in dinosaurs, (ii) the evolution of a small brain relative to body size in birds, (iii) the evolution of a large brain relative to body size in mammals, and (iv) the evolution of a small brain relative to body size in reptiles.

Cancer is a complex disease, and the search for effective therapies continues. In this study, we show that the mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a critical regulator of cancer cell metabolism and invasiveness. These findings suggest that targeting TRAP1 may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is involved in many cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. ADF is also involved in the assembly of the mitotic spindle. ADF is a monomeric protein that forms oligomers in the cytoplasm. In the nucleus, it forms a ring-like structure, which is thought to be important for the regulation of nuclear dynamics. In the cytoplasm, ADF is thought to be involved in the regulation of actin filament dynamics. In this study, we show that ADF is involved in severing actin filaments. We show that the action of ADF is enhanced by mechanical forces. We also show that the action of ADF is enhanced by twisting forces. These results are important for understanding the action of ADF in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in processed foods. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history is complex, with a recent demographic growth and a sex-biased colonization. In addition, we find that the present genomic diversity is influenced by geography, suggesting that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for future studies on the history of the Indian Ocean. We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with those others. This is a form of emotional contagion, and it is a powerful force in society.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is widespread and has been shown to impact the function of the RNA. However, the impact of mRNA modifications on the translation of the RNA is not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can modestly alter the rate of translation and the products of translation. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a subtle impact on the decoding of the mRNA. This study provides a foundation for future studies that will explore the impact of mRNA modifications on the translation of the RNA. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is meaningful and worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of health and social outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as socioeconomic status, education, and sex. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense the presence of surfaces. This sensing mechanism is essential for the regulation of the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The pili-mediated surface sensing system is a unique example of a mechanosensitive system in bacteria.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide problem. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is widespread and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Here, we describe the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also describe the rapid spread of the virus within the deer population. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatment is a major public health concern. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are deposited in the brain and form neurotoxic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, respectively. However, the immune system is also activated in the brain during AD, and the role of the immune system in AD pathogenesis is not well understood. Here, we show that neurons are also activated in the brain during AD, and that this neuron-specific immune response may be a significant contributor to AD pathogenesis. Our findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be a key event in the initiation of AD, and that targeting this event may be a promising strategy for the treatment of AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the earliest known site where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced is the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to RNA caps, which are required for their biological activity. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing those caps, inactivated by stress, is also the one that prefers to remove capped RNAs over their capped counterparts. This enzyme, which recognizes capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, generates a one-nucleotide-long RNA product, which must be further degraded to generate the monophosphorylated 5′ terminus needed to stimulate rapid RNA decay. The unconventional manner in which this enzyme recognizes capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is involved in the development of a proinflammatory state during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The results of these studies could lead to the development of a new class of drugs to treat sepsis. This would be a significant advance in the treatment of this condition.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics where systems with no external control parameter reach a critical state with self-sustained activity. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is a hallmark of criticality. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we describe a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without defects or impurities, by applying strain. This opens up opportunities to tailor the properties of diamond for specific applications.

The role of plant immune system in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the role of fungal pathogens in the defense against plant immune system is less understood. Here, we show that the antifungal activity of a legume nodule-specific peptide against plant fungal pathogens is mediated by the plant immune system. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to bind to plant immune system molecules, which leads to the disruption of the plant immune system. The peptide is also able to penetrate the fungal cell wall and cell membrane, and induce reactive oxygen species, which leads to the death of the fungal pathogen. The peptide is also able to bind to plant immune system molecules, which leads to the disruption of the plant immune system.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the origins of species differences. However, the extent to which the female contributes to the development of the male is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female contributes to the development of the male, and that this contribution is critical for sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies that will elucidate the extent to which the female contributes to the development of the male. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to control bleeding. The A1 domain in VWF is important for this function. We show that force application to platelets switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of VWF function. The results are also relevant to understanding the role of force in other biological systems.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been largely ignored. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human virome, and provides a resource for future studies.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is mainly due to the lack of observational capability. The dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) is a new instrument that can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important because it affects the evolution of life, and because it is a key factor in the formation of the atmosphere. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has been inferred from a variety of methods, including the isotopic composition of marine sediments. However, the reliability of these methods has been questioned. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of enzymes.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous and cardiovascular systems. The pore gates of ion channels are the main sites of ion flow regulation. We studied the relationship between the activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery of the K+ channel, the BK channel. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion flow and the development of new drugs. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The Plasmodium parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is a complex event, and the role of the host RBC in the process is poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, which may help to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host RBC are working together to facilitate invasion. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the invasion process is a dynamic process, with multiple forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the invasion process and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat malaria.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without defects or impurities, by applying strain. This opens up opportunities to tailor the properties of diamond for specific applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The impact of environmental factors on influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of environmental factors on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection and disease severity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words, but there is no direct evidence that this is actually done. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This suggests that the brain is able to identify the structure of sentences, and that the merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream.

The Wnt signaling pathway is one of the most important pathways in development. It is also a target of cancer. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently in different tissues. This differential regulation may be important for the proper functioning of the pathway in different tissues.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the search for its causes is ongoing. Here we describe a circuit in the brain that may contribute to overeating. This circuit is activated by electrical or optogenetic stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, a region that is activated by ingesting food. This activation, in turn, causes animals to eat more. We show that this circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and that dopamine lesions or antagonists block the effect. We also show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus causes animals to eat more when dopamine neurons are blocked. Finally, we show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus causes animals to eat more when dopamine neurons are blocked.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is the main factor limiting crop yields. The use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture has been limited by the lack of a sustainable way to control the release of nitrogen from the bacteria to the plant. Here, we demonstrate that the production of a bacterial signal by the plant can be used to control the expression of genes that control the availability of nitrogen to the plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could lead to a sustainable way to deliver nitrogen to the plant and thus contribute to a more sustainable agriculture.

The Amazon is losing forest cover at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are often generated before they are detected by local communities, which are the most directly affected by deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the complexity of the program and the small number of communities that participated. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide variety of hearing organs, but they are all made of tissue and are part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has an auditory organ that is not constrained by the body and is extended to its web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is more sensitive to sound than the eardrum of any other animal. The spider can remotely sense the direction and location of the sound source, and it can also adjust and regenerate the web to suit its needs. This provides a unique model for studying the outsourcing and supersizing of sensing and for designing novel acoustic flow detectors.

The health and climate impacts of human activities are often considered separately. We show that the health benefits of reducing greenhouse gas emissions are much larger than previously thought. We also show that aerosols, which are a major contributor to climate change, are responsible for a large fraction of the excess mortality from outdoor air pollution. Our results suggest that the health benefits of reducing greenhouse gases are even larger than previously thought. This study provides a framework for a more holistic approach to the assessment of the impacts of human activities on the environment and human health. It also provides a basis for a more effective policy to reduce the negative impacts of human activities.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the virus. Here we describe a strategy to improve the immunogenicity of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, which is the target of most vaccines in development. We show that the immunogenicity of the RBD can be improved by engineering it to have a different sequence than the one used in the currently approved vaccines. This engineered RBD can be expressed in bacteria and can be used to generate virus-like particles that can protect hamsters from viral infection. These results suggest that this engineered RBD could be used in the development of vaccines against COVID-19. This approach could be used to improve the immunogenicity of other subunit vaccines as well. (Show more)

The role of the ALK/ALKALS receptor–ligand system in the development of neural crest-derived tissues is unknown. Here, we show that the zebrafish ALK/ALKALS system is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the eye. We provide evidence that the ALK/ALKALS system is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues in vivo. Our results provide insights into the role of the ALK/ALKALS system in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Y. pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of genomes from this period is too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. These data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support

The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. However, the extent to which these changes are occurring is highly uncertain. We show that the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols can affect the amount of C stored in the soil. We found that the management of perennial pastures with rotational grazing can increase the amount of C stored in the soil, whereas the management of annual cropping systems can decrease the amount of C stored in the soil. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and used this to rank the zoonotic potential of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery and surveillance efforts, and demonstrated the utility of the framework in a case study. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals and is often used to infer the function of nectar. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of the red pigment, and we show that the same three enzymes are also involved in the production of the yellow nectar of the related species Jaltomata herrerae. These findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is favored by natural selection.

The history of Europe is marked by complex demographic processes, which have shaped the genetic landscape of the continent. However, the analysis of the genetic history of the European population during the period of cultural change is hampered by the lack of genome data from a large number of individuals. Here we present a study of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had skull deformations that were surgically corrected in the 6th century AD. Our analysis of their collective genetic ancestry indicates that they had a genetic ancestry that was different from that of the rest of the population. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the history of Europe and the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of the continent.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and may help in the development of strategies to prevent future bat-to-human spill

The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. The emergence of new pathogens, such as COVID-19, has highlighted the need for rapid and accurate diagnostics. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a powerful tool for the rapid detection of pathogens in clinical samples. However, mNGS is resource intensive and requires bioinformatics expertise. Here, we describe a method for mNGS analysis that is simple, cost-effective, and can be performed on the global cloud. We demonstrate the utility of this method in a resource-scarce setting in Cambodia, where we identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This method can be used to identify the regional pathogen landscape and to better understand the burden of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. Ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This method can be used to better understand the burden of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings.

The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the role of the sliding clamp in regulating the processivity and stability of the DNA polymerase holoenzyme. It also provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of the sliding clamp in the regulation of lagging strand synthesis. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of the genetic code, information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by an RNA polymerase ribozyme. In the laboratory, the activity of this ribozyme can be improved by in vitro evolution, but the ability to replicate RNA is still lacking. Here, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA, thus completing the set of necessary activities for the origin of life. This work represents a major step toward the construction of a functional RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 have been analyzed. The pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality. These findings provide a reference for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The fungal cell has evolved a variety of mechanisms to maintain copper at appropriate levels. The role of the xan BGC in the maintenance of copper homeostasis is demonstrated here.

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica that is a product of high-temperature, aqueous silica-rich fluids. Tridymite is a common product of silicic volcanism, and it is possible that the Marias Pass region was once volcanically active. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment can account for the cogenetic detrital phases at Marias Pass. Opaline silica could form during diagenesis from high-SiO2 glass, as amorphous precipitated silica, or as a residue of acidic leaching in the sediment source region or at Marias Pass. The amorphous mixed-cation salts and oxides and possibly the crystalline magnetite (otherwise detrital) are primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products derived from multiple infiltrations of aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. Anhydrite is post lithification fracture/vein fill.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of this risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new risk. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which is unable to induce colitis in a Th17 transfer model. This subset is dependent on Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors, and is required for the development of colitis. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This dual role for Th17 cells may be important in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by the degeneration of motor neurons, which are the only cells in the body that do not have a regenerative capacity. The disease is progressive and leads to death within a few years. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. We have developed a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes. These astrocytes are highly toxic to motor neurons, and we have identified a common mechanism of toxicity between ALS patients with different genetic causes. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will lead to the development of new therapies for ALS. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. We now show that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to enhance the ability of the pathogen to colonize the tick. We also show that the ability of Anaplasma to modify the tick microbiota is mediated by the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which is a protein that is expressed in the gut of the tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, which results in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can use the host vector to enhance its transmission. This knowledge will be useful in the development of strategies to control the transmission of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The origin of the avian tail and the evolution of flight are among the most important evolutionary questions in biology. The discovery of a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail (pygostylians) provides new insights into the origin of the modern avian form.

We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system. This is a significant finding because the stratosphere is often thought of as a “stable” region of the atmosphere, but it is now clear that it is an active region that responds to changes in the troposphere.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, ranging from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can affect its ability to blend in with its environment. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) can be modified by the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main component of the hemoglobin of vertebrates. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of the color of anurans, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of the molecular mechanisms that regulate the development and progression of this disease is critical to the development of new therapies. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a breast cancer stem cell factor. This study provides a mechanism for the role of ALKBH5 in the development of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily torn. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides.
