The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter for understanding the causes and consequences of the event. The age model for the extinction is based on a new set of U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The dates define an age of 251.941 ± 0.037 to 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya for the extinction, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the dates provide a means to evaluate the role of carbon cycle changes in the extinction. The dates also provide a precise age for the beginning of the recovery of marine and terrestrial ecosystems. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the site of immune surveillance and the first line of defense against invading pathogens. The intestinal epithelium is composed of multiple cell types, including the absorptive enterocytes, immune cells, and the supporting stromal cells. The intestinal epithelium is constantly exposed to a variety of environmental stimuli, which are sensed by the intestinal epithelium and transmitted to the immune system. In this review, we focus on the role of retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) in the intestinal epithelium and its potential as a therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. We also discuss the importance of RORα in the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis and the role of RORα in the development of inflammatory diseases. Finally, we discuss the potential of RORα as a therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating virus and is thought to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the mutant spike is in a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results provide insight into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike and may inform the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and biology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. These results are of fundamental importance in chemistry and biology, and can be used to predict and explain the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure. Furthermore, the results are of great interest for the development of new materials under pressure.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in the climate system is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in global fire activity. This has the potential to reduce warming, but only if it is sustained. Our results suggest that the role of fire in the climate system is likely to be underestimated in climate models.

The immune system of animals is often associated with the production of a large variety of molecules that are released in the body fluids. However, in some cases, the immune system is involved in the maintenance of a specific symbiont, which is usually located in the epithelium. In this study, we show that the immune system of the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of the symbiotic bacteria that live in the epithelium. This is achieved by the strategic release of a single glycan, which is catabolized by the symbionts. This glycan is used by the symbionts to maintain a specific pH in their habitat, which is required for their activity. This study provides a new perspective on the role of the immune system in the maintenance of symbiosis.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is illustrated with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to any domain, and the resulting topics can be interpreted as latent topics, as latent features, or as a combination of both. Our method is also easily extendable to other types of data.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally accepted that the disease originated in Asia and was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, the exact location of the first introduction of the bacterium Yersinia pestis is still debated. We show that the climate conditions in the Asian and European harbors that were most likely to have been the first introduction sites were favorable for the spread of the disease. Our results suggest that the disease was reintroduced into Europe several times, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y each time. This suggests that the disease was not established in Europe for a long time after the first introduction.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. They are also a valuable resource for humans. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has led to the mass mortality of thousands of individuals. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the tissues. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by starfish.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The recent history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island shows that the settlement was not homogeneous, and that the admixture was sex biased. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. Our approach can also be extended to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and drugs against other viruses. Agricultural production is a key driver of the global economy, and the ability to monitor crop status in space and time is critical to manage production. Current systems, however, are limited in their ability to capture the complexities of crop status, and are often based on a single source of information, such as satellite imagery, which is not always available. We propose a system that uses the collective knowledge of many crop experts to provide a more complete picture of crop status. Our system is based on a network of “people as sensors” that provide information on crop status through a simple survey. We show that this system is robust, stable, and can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our system can be easily adapted to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. This mechanism is not based on the maintenance of elevated firing rates or on the use of inhibitory feedback. It is also not based on the use of persistent activity. This mechanism is therefore suitable for the integration of information over time in sequence processing within the language domain.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture data, representing 27 temperature manipulation studies. Our analysis provides evidence that soil respiration may not be increasing in response to warming in many biomes, contrary to the results from single-site studies. This suggests that the response of soil respiration to warming may be highly variable across the globe, and that future studies should focus on understanding the mechanisms behind this variability.

The plastid genome is a unique genetic element that has been shaped by the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus. The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a key factor in the evolution of the plant kingdom. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plants. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water availability in South Africa. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100 under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results suggest that the drought risk in SSA will increase substantially in the coming decades, and that adaptation strategies are urgently needed. This study provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought in SSA. It also provides a useful tool for the development of adaptation strategies. (Less)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Like the naturally formed quasicrystals found in the Khatyrka meteorite and experimental shock syntheses of quasicrystals, the anthropogenic quasicrystals in red trinitite demonstrate that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1 in astrocytes also plays a role in neuroinflammation, but its role is more prominent in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for mapping out causal paths in autism. It also provides a potential target for the development of a Drosophila model system for autism. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in Stormorken syndrome, a rare disease of hematopoietic and skeletal muscle. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates causes neuronal death. Finally, we show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on active release and uptake of aggregates. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of spreading of neurodegenerative disease. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential for MTX to be used as a therapeutic target to control viral infections. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic processes that supports cell growth is the conversion of serine to glycine, which is then used to synthesize DNA and RNA. The enzyme responsible for this reaction is serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). In this study, we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells leads to cell death. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2 and use it to identify a cancer cell-line screen. This screen reveals that B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. We show that this sensitivity is rooted in defective glycine import, which is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. This study identifies a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or treatment. The disease is caused by the aggregation of mutant proteins, which are also aggregation-prone. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal system is predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for exploring a variety of fundamental and applied research topics in the fields of quantum materials and quantum technologies. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The earliest flowering plants are poorly known, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is still a matter of debate. The study of the earliest flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils, and the study of the earliest flowering plants in aquatic habitats is even more difficult. The study of Montsechia, a very early flowering plant from the Cretaceous, is a step forward in the understanding of the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but the evolution of the human pathogen parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been difficult to study. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 thousand years ago) and show that they are closely related to the most recent common ancestor of all B19V. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also provides a unique resource for future studies of the evolution of B19V and other viruses. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is a result of a combination of natural processes and human activities. The acceleration is a result of the combined effects of global warming and the thermal expansion of the oceans and ice sheets melting or retreating. This paper provides a simple, straightforward, and robust estimate of the acceleration of global mean sea level.

Pain is also increasing with education, but this pattern is not seen for all Americans. Together, these findings suggest that the erosion of working-class life is having a negative impact on the health of the American people.

Suspension rates are rising in the United States, and the consequences are severe. In this research, we show that teachers can be trained to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which in turn reduces suspension rates. This is a scalable, evidence-based intervention that can be implemented in schools across the country.

However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. We show that the first cleavages are significant for MERS-CoV infection, because they are required for virions to use cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, and because the more rigid uncleaved viruses are less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages are significant for MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of this problem. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a university cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8%. This is a large effect, and it is likely that similar increases in the proportion of vegetarian meals served could be achieved in other settings. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals served in catering outlets could make a significant contribution to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. They also suggest that simple changes to catering practices could be used to nudge people toward more sustainable diets. This approach could be used to help achieve the goals of the Sustainable Development Goals.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a dynamic and complex system. Here we apply a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer and other diseases. (Show more)

The 2020 presidential election will be the first in which many voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with the development of vaccines and therapeutics being the only way to contain it. However, the mechanisms by which the virus causes disease are largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. We show that the structure is similar to that of SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, but with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may be important for the immune evasion and spread of the virus. The structure provides a basis for the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex to trigger the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), which contribute to the development of edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and suggest that the CRF system could be a potential target for the treatment of this condition. This knowledge could also be applied to the treatment of other conditions involving edema, such as brain edema in traumatic brain injury. The world is full of associations. We are surrounded by them: the association between the color of our car and our likelihood of being late, the association between the number of hours we spend on Facebook and our happiness, the association between the amount of money we spend on our children and their future success. We are also surrounded by methods for finding associations. We can use these methods to find associations in our own data, or we can use them to find associations in the world around us. In this article, we describe a way of using these methods that is more careful about what we claim to have found.

The development of vascular networks is a key process in the formation of organs. In this study, we demonstrate that the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) is sufficient to induce the formation of vascular networks in vivo. This finding provides a new strategy for the development of vascular networks in the regeneration of organs. It also provides a new approach for the treatment of vascular diseases. This study will contribute to the development of vascular networks in the regeneration of organs and the treatment of vascular diseases.

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes. In the past decade, two additional RTKs have been identified that are involved in cancer development: anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). Here, we show that zebrafish, a model organism, can be used to study the physiological function of these two RTKs. We show that zebrafish deficient in Ltk display a severe defect in iridophore patterning, which is completely rescued by a specific ligand of Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system to study the role of RTKs in development and cancer. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular basis of T2D is still unclear, insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated. Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING deficiency alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis suggested that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and are also responsible for occasional severe pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly regulated process, and the existence of a selective packaging mechanism is suspected. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that YAP/TAZ are activated by disturbed flow and promote the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggests a potential target for the development of athero-protective drugs. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a significant threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to the loss of forest and rangeland. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study is also relevant to the study of the evolution of ion channels. The results are expected to contribute to the conservation of biodiversity and the rational design of insect control strategy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid rise of the viral load, the short eclipse phase, and the rapid clearance of the virus. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment and to assess the potential of a new drug, favipiravir, to reduce the viral load and shorten the time to viral clearance. The model can be used to guide the design of future experiments and to assess the impact of control measures. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most important factors in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is the breakdown of the mutualistic relationship between the host and its algal symbionts. This process is often referred to as bleaching, and it is a major cause of coral mortality. Here, we show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a key factor in the early stages of bleaching. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to preserve this important ecosystem.

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes dysregulated, leading to the loss of this barrier function. Here, we show that the tumorigenic response of the epithelium can trigger a feedback loop that leads to the loss of the intestinal barrier and the dysbiosis of the microbiome. We also show that restoring the activity of the microbiome can restore the barrier function of the epithelium. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. It also identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to this treatment is heterogeneous. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice, and that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is more effective than treatment with either chemotherapy alone. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This study also provides a rationale for the use of cirmtuzumab in combination with chemotherapy in the treatment of patients with breast cancer. The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is controversial, with some studies suggesting that deglaciation began as early as ∼18 ka. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which, in turn, led to a rapid climate response. This is the first time that a volcanic eruption has been linked to deglaciation, and it provides a unique opportunity to study the impact of human-caused ozone depletion on climate.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished. However, the high dependence of poor and rural communities on inland fisheries makes them vulnerable to overfishing and degradation. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are a priority for conservation and restoration. This information can be used to inform environmental planning and improve the management of freshwater fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. Aqueous Li-ion batteries are promising for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity is lost during development and is never regained. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has important implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination events in the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in regions of the genome that are rich in genes and that the distribution of recombination events is highly conserved across eukaryotes. These results provide a detailed view of the process of meiosis in a flowering plant and will be useful for future studies of the genetics of this important group of organisms.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing the activity of a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of nodes (brain regions) and edges (cortical connections), which are functionally and anatomically connected to each other. Here, we show that the dominant component of the metabolic signal, which represents total brain activity, is topographically similar to the default mode network in healthy subjects. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant component is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the metabolic RSNs during task performance. We found that the dominant component of the metabolic signal was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work illustrates the potential of metabolic imaging to provide information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for the stability and translation of mRNA. The 5′ cap structure is also found on some small RNAs. Here we show that the 5′ cap structure is not unique to eukaryotes. We also show that the 5′ cap structure is not the only modification of mRNA. We describe a new modification, 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+), and show that it is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs.

Diabetes is a major public health problem. The long-term complications of diabetes are associated with persistent hyperglycemia. We hypothesized that epigenetic DNA-me alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with the metabolic memory of intensive vs. conventional therapy in people with diabetes. We found that DNA-me alterations at certain loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC is unknown. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This study may also be relevant to other cancers with autophagy and AMPK signaling as therapeutic targets.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the changes in the gut barrier. These findings suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of many plant species, and the identification of the enzymes responsible for their production is a major step forward in understanding the mechanisms of their biosynthesis. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the known nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the production of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the mechanisms of volatile production in plants and opens the way to the development of new strategies for the improvement of the flavor of tomato and other fruit crops. Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these two threats are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the future of the Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large number of neurons that are tuned to different aspects of the environment, such as the location of walls and the direction of travel. These neurons are organized in a topographic fashion, such that neurons that are close to each other are also active together. The organization of these neurons is important for understanding how the brain represents the environment and how this representation is used for navigation. Here, we show that the organization of these neurons is also important for navigation.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This is a unique means of flowering regulation and illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We have long sought to understand how we know when two people are connecting with each other. We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by others to judge the quality of the connection between two people, and it is used by the people themselves to gauge their own connection with others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for maintaining a normal heart rate in response to changes in the environment. The SAN is a highly regulated system that is sensitive to changes in the environment. In this study, we show that the activity of the SAN is regulated by stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1). STIM1 is a calcium sensor that is involved in the regulation of calcium signaling in many different cell types. Our results suggest that STIM1 is involved in the regulation of the SAN and that it may be a potential target for the treatment of heart disease. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivory has not been well established. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the plant defense response against insect herbivory. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is simple, elegant, and provides a unified account of a number of different phenomena.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical bottleneck in the field of synthetic biology. This is due to the lack of a delivery mechanism that can deliver functional biomolecules to plant cells. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiency. This work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of a synthetic biology platform for plants.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can alter the structure and function of coastal ecosystems. The impact of nutrient loading on the nearshore zone is largely unknown because of a lack of information on the relative importance of small tributaries. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to the nearshore zone of large lakes. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable coastal ecosystems. This is especially important in the Great Lakes, where the nearshore zone is a valuable resource for recreation and commerce.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We show that the saddle-node bifurcation is a generic feature of the dynamics of this network, and we discuss the implications of this result for the study of complex systems.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, which in turn alters the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and show that the same changes in microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same changes in microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. This may explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. Our findings may also have implications for the treatment of NMDAR-Abs.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 y. The cause of this warming is still debated, but it is likely that the warming is caused by human activities. To understand the causes of the current warming, it is important to understand the causes of past warming events. Here, we present a case study of a past warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was caused by a rapid injection of organic matter into the ocean, which led to anoxia and a doubling of atmospheric CO2.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a key topic in developmental biology. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination loci in a fish species, where two female-determining alleles interact to produce siblings with four possible sex classes. We find that the modular interplay of sex determination alleles produces variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and behavior. These results provide context for understanding the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of photooxidatively modified lipids. These lipids, which are the products of photooxidation, are further oxidized and degraded, leading to the loss of photoreceptor cells. We show that the levels of iron in the retina impact the accumulation of these photooxidatively modified lipids. This finding has implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the diversity of their feeding strategies is a key factor in the diversity of their prey. However, the evolution of predatory specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved a modular morphology that allows them to capture prey in a highly specialized way. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological innovations. This perspective helps us understand how specialization has shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex structure with a long evolutionary history. The fossil record of the hominin hand is fragmentary, and the origin of the distinctive features of the modern human hand is poorly understood. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the origin of this feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding is important for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human tool use. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the most important steps in this process is the synthesis of DNA, which requires the one-carbon unit provided by the amino acid serine. The enzyme that provides this one-carbon unit is serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). In this study, we show that the inhibition of SHMT is a promising strategy to treat cancer.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by having access to natural landscapes such as forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also a major cause of soil degradation. Soil compaction is a major threat to soil productivity, and it is caused by the weight of farm machinery. We show that the weight of modern farm machinery has increased over the last century, and that this trend has been accompanied by an increase in subsoil compaction. We also show that the weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that the roaming of these giants may have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles.
